Award.AwardTitle: Self-Stressing Shape Memory Alloys/Fiber Reinforced Polymer (SMA/FRP) Composite Patches for Rehabilitation of Cracked Steel Structures

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to investigate the use of novel "self-stressing" composite patches to retrofit such cracked steel structures. Steel structures, such as bridge girders, are susceptible to fatigue cracking under the effect of repeated loading conditions. These cracks grow with time and if unchecked they can compromise structural integrity and potentially even lead to complete collapse of the structure. The patches are made of fiber reinforced polymer composites with embedded shape memory alloy strands which provide the self pre-stressing properties of the patches. The patches will be bonded to the surface of cracked steel structures using a structural adhesive to enhance the fatigue lives of the retrofitted structures. To achieve this objective, the project will be conducted in three phases. In the first phase, a series of shape memory alloy composite patches will be tested to evaluate the effect of different parameters on the patch pre-stressing characteristics. The second phase will consists of testing small-scale and large-scale cracked structural members reinforced with patches to quantify the fatigue life increase that can be achieved in steel structures. In the third phase, a numerical model will be developed to predict the behavior of cracked steel members that are repaired using the self-stressing patches. The success of this project will lead to the development of an innovative new approach for repairing cracked steel and other metallic structures. The project will also establish a numerical framework to predict the behavior of the retrofitted structures.

The approach developed in this project to retrofit cracked structures has broad applications in several fields including marine, aerospace, and offshore energy structures. The research results will be broadly disseminated through the development of course modules, presentation at national and international conferences, and publication in archival technical journals. The project will provide advanced training to graduate students through their involvement in the project research work. The research team will work closely with existing outreach programs at the University of Houston to recruit graduate students, and provide mentorship to students from traditionally under-represented groups. The research team will also interface with existing NSF-supported outreach programs to provide educational opportunities and instructional materials to high-school students and teachers.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

Strengthening and repairing fatigue sensitive or cracked metallic structures is an important task to mitigate the damage, extend the life (i.e. the number of loading cycles before failure), and prevent the failure of these structures. Through this project a new type of thermally-activated shape memory alloy (SMA)/fiber-reinforced polymer (FRP) composite patch was developed to improve the fatigue capacity (the number of loading cycles before failure) of metallic components. The patch is externally bonded to the surface of a cracked metallic element to bridge the crack. In addition, the patch applies a prestressing force by activating the SMA wires to further close the crack. The combined effect substantially slows down the crack propagation rate in the element and hence extends the service life of the structure.

The effectiveness of the composite patch was assessed through an experimental program including fatigue testing of twenty-seven steel coupons with crack-sensitive details. The results indicate that the developed SMA/FRP patch is three times better than traditional FRP patches in extending the average service life of fatigue sensitive metallic elements. The average fatigue life of steel elements that were repaired with the developed SMA/FRP patch was up to 26 times that of un-repaired elements. This indicates that the developed composite is a promising alternative for retrofitting fatigue-sensitive details in metallic structures.

Through this project a numerical modeling approach was also developed to predict the fatigue behavior of metallic elements that are reinforced with SMA/FRP composite patches. A comparison between the predicited fatigue lives and the measured fatigue lives for steel elements with different patch configurations indicates that the numerical model provides accurate predictions of the expected fatigue lives.

Broader impacts

This project has advanced the state-of-knowledge and state-of-the-art in the field of repair of metallic structures. The research products can have broad applicability in a number of industry sectors including transportation infrastructure, energy, marine, aerospace, commercial structures and manufacturing facilities.

This project formed the basis for the dissertations of two doctoral students. It also provided research training opportunities for one other doctoral student, and seven undergraduate students from traditionally underrepresented groups. It also provided research experience and experimental data for a high school teacher in developing mathematical models for the statistic course in the high school. This project also provided an opportunity for collaboration with a team of five undergraduate students from the College of Business who received training in technology entrepreneurship and presented the developed technology at a local business competition through the Wolff Center for Entrepreneurship.

The developed SMA/FRP patch concept was introduced to representatives from local, regional, and national industries including manufacturing, oil and gas, aerospace, and automotive sectors through an annual Optical Metrology Workshop that is hosted at the University of Houston. In collaboration with a National Science Foundation Innovation Corps program, the commercial potential of the developed technology was investigated through interviews with key figures in commercial building design companies, wind energy companies, offshore oil companies, and state and federal agencies. The research findings have been broadly disseminated through publication and presentation at various international conferences and through the publication of four journal papers and one patent application with four other journal papers under review or in preparation.

The combined effect substantially slows down the crack propagation rate in the element and hence extends the service life of the structure. The effectiveness of the composite patch was assessed through an experimental program including fatigue testing of twenty-seven steel coupons with crack-sensitive details. The results indicate that the developed SMA/FRP patch is three times better than traditional FRP patches in extending the average service life of fatigue sensitive metallic elements. Through this project a numerical modeling approach was also developed to predict the fatigue behavior of metallic elements that are reinforced with SMA/FRP composite patches. The developed SMA/FRP patch concept was introduced to representatives from local, regional, and national industries including manufacturing, oil and gas, aerospace, and automotive sectors through an annual Optical Metrology Workshop that is hosted at the University of Houston.
